Krishna Kumari a b B. Srinivasa Rao a b D. Mallesh a b N. Lingaiah a b ⁎ a Department of Catalysis and Fine Chemicals, CSIR-Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad 500 007, India Department of Catalysis and Fine Chemicals CSIR-Indian Institute of Chemical Technology Hyderabad 500 007 India aDepartment of Catalysis and Fine Chemicals, CSIR-Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad 500 007, India b Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (CSIR-AcSIR), Ghaziabad 201002, India Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (CSIR-AcSIR) Ghaziabad 201002 India bAcademy of Scientific and Innovative Research (CSIR-AcSIR), Ghaziabad 201002, India ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Catalysis and Fine Chemicals, CSIR-Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad 500 007, India. Department of Catalysis and Fine Chemicals CSIR-Indian Institute of Chemical Technology Hyderabad 500 007 India Various niobium contained tungstophosphoric acid (NbTPA) supported on titania catalysts were prepared and investigated their activity for selective synthesis of 5-ethoxymethylfurfural (EMF) from fructose in ethanol/THF solvent system. Physico-chemical properties of the catalysts were assessed by different spectroscopic approaches like X-ray diffraction, Laser Raman, BET-surface area, FT-IR, pyridine adsorbed FT-IR and temperature programmed desorption of ammonia. The results of characterization direct the existence of firm Keggin ion structure of Nb exchanged TPA and its well dispersed state on support. Lewis acidic sites were induced with the existence of Nb ions. The catalytic activity was interrelated to the catalyst acidity which was liable on the number of Nb ions present in TPA and the amount of NbxTPA supported on TiO2. Among all catalysts 20wt% Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 catalyst showed best catalytic performance towards EMF with a yield of 76% at 130 οC after 6 h. The catalyst is recyclable without any depletion of activity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Fructose Biomass 5-ethoxymethylfurfural Ethyl levulinate Tungstophosphoric acid 1 Introduction The down fall of fossil fuel resources, accompanied by raised call for conventional fuels and intensifying alarms about unfriendly environment, strains the world towards the discover of replenishment renewable feedstocks [1,2]. In this context, biomass may partially substitute and balance the non-renewable fossil incomes envisioned for the wide-ranging manufacture of fuels and chemicals [3,4]. Growing consideration has been put on resourceful valorisation of biomass derived carbohydrates to valuable platform molecules such as 5-hydroxymethyfurfural (HMF), furfural and liquid fuels [5,6]. Among several biomass derived products, 5-ethoxymethylfurfural (EMF) have been received extensive attention, which is generated through acid-catalysed etherification of 5-hydroxymethyfurfural with ethanol [7,8]. EMF has greater fuel properties like high energy density, high cetane number, good stability and low toxicity. Owing to its good fuel properties, EMF can be used as a good fuel additive. When blending with diesel creates fewer fine particles and SO2 emissions [9–11]. Right now, different approaches on EMF production were accessible such as treatment of 5-(chloromethyl) furfural (CMF), direct HMF etherification with ethanol and dehydrative etherification of hexoses like fructose and glucose [12,13]. Numerous catalysts, such as poly oxometallates [14], mineral acids [15] and inorganic salts [16,17] were experimented for EMF synthesis. However, most of these catalysts are soluble in reaction mixture makes tough job in recovery process. Instead of that, use of heterogeneous catalysts makes the process simple and facile. Consequently, many research groups developed heterogeneous catalytic systems for selective synthesis of EMF from different biomass products. Solid acid catalysts such as ZrO2/SBA-15, SO4-ZrO2/SBA-15 [18], graphene oxide (GO) [19] and HPA based catalysts like [BmimSO3H]3PW12O40 [20] Ag1H2PW [21], Cs2STA [22] and immobilized HPAs on different supports like K-10 clay [23], MCM-41 [24], cellulose-SO3H [25] were tested for EMF production from HMF. Etherification of HMF and nucleophilic substitution of 5-(chloromethyl) furfural with ethanol [26] are most effective ways to get more yield of EMF. However, large scale production of EMF from catalytic systems for HMF etherification and CMF treatment were inadequate owing to the high price of HMF, issue of harmful nature of HCl generation after nucleophilic substitution of Cl with ethanol in CMF. In this scenario, hexoses are favoured feedstocks to produce EMF through one-pot approach. As the use of glucose feedstock necessitates an isomerization step of glucose to fructose, it’s a difficult approach, needs specific properties of catalysts and gives lesser EMF yield. Both fructose dehydration into HMF and subsequently HMF etherification into EMF are acid catalysed reactions, gives better yield of EMF compared to glucose as a feedstock. It is rational to integrate the two discrete reactions into one-pot reaction by using fructose as feed to produce EMF. The two step dehydrative etherification of fructose to EMF reaction is shown in Scheme 1 . Many researchers have premeditated for one pot synthesis of EMF from fructose along with HMF. Recently, Yin et al. [27] studied Fe3O4@SiO2-SH-Im-HSO4 catalyst for synthesis of EMF from fructose and they reported 60% of EMF at 120 °C after 24 h. Balakrishnan et al. [15] testified silica sulfuric acid and Amberlyst-15 resin catalysts in order to produce EMF from fructose and attained around 69, 71% of EMF yields respectively at 110 °C after 30 h. Hu Li et al. [28] reached comparatively more produce of EMF with about 77% yield from fructose at 120 °C after 15 h in EtOH/DMSO solvent system by using acid–base hybrid nanosphere catalyst, together with heteropoly tungstate and amino acids. Different catalytic systems like Ag1H2PW [21], cellulose-SO3H [25], MCM-41-HPW [24], K-10 clay-HPW [23], poly (VMPS)-PW [29] were also assessed for EMF production from both fructose and HMF. In the direction of EMF synthesis from fructose by earlier reported systems required longer reaction time and high catalyst loadings. In this context, development of effective catalysts is still required for selective production of EMF from fructose. Along with various capable acid catalysts, heteropoly acids (HPAs) also can be used as a good applicant for acid catalysed reactions [30,31]. However, the nature of solubility in polar solvent system makes problematic in parting of catalyst from reaction mixture. To avoid these issues, renovate the HPAs into heterogeneous by replacing the protons with metal ions (Ta, Ti, Cs, Fe, Ag) [32,33] and diffusing them on various supports like SiO2 based mesoporous materials (SBA-15, SBA-16, MCM-41) [34,24], zeolites, metal phosphates (NbP, TiP, ZrP) [35] and metal oxides (Nb2O5, ZrO2, TiO2, SnO2) etc. [33,36]. Based on the nature of the reaction and reported catalysts, it is essential that the catalyst should have both Lewis and Bronsted acidic sites to obtain better activity in the synthesis of EMF directly from fructose. It is planned to modify the Bronsted acidic heteropolytungstate with Nb ions to create Lewis acidic sites to be used as catalyst for EMF synthesis. In present study, niobium (Nb) exchanged tungstophosphoric acid (TPA) was prepared by replacing the protons of TPA with Nb metal ions and dispersing them on titania (TiO2) support. These catalysts were studied for selective preparation of EMF from fructose in one-pot strategy. The various characterization techniques were used to recognize the catalysts properties and their activity was correlated based on their characteristic data. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Nb exchanged TPA dispersed on TiO2 catalysts were developed in two steps by impregnation approach [37]. Firstly, tungstophosphoric acid dispersed on titania (TPA/TiO2) samples were prepared. The requisite quantity of TPA was dissolved in distilled water and this solution was added to TiO2 in drop wise with stirring. Subsequently stirring continued for 30 min, then the excess water was vanished by rota evaporator, dried in oven for overnight at100 οC and the samples were calcined at 300 οC for 2 h. Finally, Nb exchanged with protons of TPA dispersed on TiO2 catalysts were prepared as above stated description of impregnation method. Planned quantity of niobium chloride (NbCl5) dissolved in distilled water was added to the TPA dispersed on TiO2 sample prepared as mention above. After exchange of Nb the sample is dried on a hot plate and finally calcined at 300 οC for 2 h. The amount of NbCl5 is fixed based on the number of TPA protons to be replaced. Then, obtained the Nb5+ metal ions replaced by the protons of TPA supported TiO2 catalysts. These were labelled as 5–25 wt% Nb x TPA/TiO2 (x = 0.2, 0.4, 0.6) and the numbers indicate the weight percentage of Nb x TPA on support. 2.2 Catalysts characterization X-ray diffraction patterns were obtained on Rigaku Miniflex diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (0.15406 nm) at 40 Kv voltage and 30 mA current. Patterns were recorded in 2θ range of 10.0–80.0° Raman spectra of catalysts were recorded on Raman spectroscopy (Horiba Jobin-Yvon Lab Ram HR spectrometer) equipped with a 17-mW internal He/Ne laser, operated at 633 nm of excitation wavelength. The powdered catalyst was spread over a glass slide and measurements were recorded by focusing at different spots in the range of 200–1200 cm−1. Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectral measurements were recorded by KBr disk technique on DIGILAB IR spectrometer (USA). Pyridine adsorbed IR spectra were attained on diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier Transform (DRIFT) mode. Proceeding to the assessment, the catalyst sample was pre-treated at 200 °C for 3 h under vacuum and pyridine was introduced. Afterwards, the sample heated for 1 h at 120 °C to get rid of any physiosorbed pyridine. Then, the sample cooled to room temperature and recorded the spectrum. Temperature programmed desorption of NH3 was attained on BELCAT-II instrument (Belsorb, Japan). Prior to the assessment, about 50 mg of sample was pre-treated for 1 h at 300 °C in 30 mL/min flow of pure He gas (99.9%). Then, the pre-treated sample was saturated by anhydrous NH3 (90% He −10% NH3 mixture gas) for 1 h at 100 °C. After that, the sample flushed with He gas at similar temperature to get rid of any physiosorbed NH3. The temperature program was performed from 100 to 800 °C with 10 °C/min elevation in temperature. The evolved quantity of NH3 was considered and calibrated via thermal conductivity detector (TCD) of the instrument. BET surface area of the prepared samples were calculated by N2 physisorption-desorption studies recorded by BEL Sorb II Instruments (Japan) at −196 οC. Before proceeding to the analysis, degassed the samples for 2 h at 200 °C. 2.3 Reaction procedure and analysis methods In a typical method of EMF synthesis from fructose, 0.180 g of fructose, ethanol/THF mixture solution (VEthanol:VTHF=3:2) and 3.35wt% of catalyst with respect to reaction mixture were added in to a 15 mL thick-enclosed glass apparatus. The reaction mixture was heated for specified reaction time at set temperature with stirring speed of 500 rpm. After desired time, the reaction was ended by placing the vessel into a cooled water bath. Then the sample was filtered, diluted and used for products investigation. The reaction mixture analysed by using a manual sampler HPLC system (SHIMADZU) equipped with binary LC-20AD pumps, and refractive index detector (RID-20A) maintained at 60 °C. The products were separated in Shodex SC1011 sugar column by using H2O as mobile phase with 0.8 mL/min flow rate. Calibration was done by using standard solutions of carbohydrates, EL, HMF and EMF. Prior to the test, samples were diluted with a known volume of millipore water and analysis was done for 3 times and testified within standard deviations of triplicates within 1.0%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization XRD patterns of bare TiO2 and Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 catalysts are presented in Fig. 1 . Characteristic peaks at 2θ of 25.50ο, 37.83ο, 48.07ο, 53.88ο, 55.02ο and 62.70ο related to the anatase form of TiO2. Furthermore, small intense peaks apparent at 27.4ο, 36.08ο, 54.3ο represents the presence of rutile form of TiO2 [38]. Representative peaks of Nb0.4TPA Keggin ion were observed at 2θ of 14.6, 30.0, 34.5 [39] for the samples with above 20wt% of Nb0.4TPA on TiO2. This outcome suggests that Nb0.4TPA was well spread on the support at lower loadings and turn out to be crystalline phase when exceeding the 20wt% Nb0.4TPA, which informs the attainment of bulk constitution on the support [8]. FT-IR spectral patterns of TPA and Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 catalysts are showed in Fig. 2 . The Keggin heteropoly TPA displayed four characteristic bands of Keggin ion at 815, 891, 986 and 1080 cm−1 allied to the asymmetric stretching vibrations of W−Oe−W, W−Oc−W, W−Ot and P − O correspondingly [6, 40]. These peaks were observed for all the Nb modified TPA supported on TiO2 catalysts. FTIR results showed that Nb0.4TPA Keggin ion structure remains intact even after its dispersion on the support. Fig. 3 a shows the Raman spectra of the catalysts. The important bands of TiO2 are observed at 394, 515 and 638 cm−1 for all the catalysts. The representative bands of Keggin ion perceived at 991 and 1009 cm−1 allied to asymmetric and symmetric stretching modes of W=Ot of steady Keggin ion [41]. The respective Keggin ion bands were clearly observed in Fig. 3b for the catalysts with above 15wt% loading indicates that structure of Keggin heteropoly tungstate was not damaged after its modifications. The characterization findings from XRD, FT-IR and laser Raman spectral studies propose the preserve of stable Nb0.4TPA Keggin ion which was well spread over the support. Pyridine adsorbed FT-IR spectra were used to distinguish the classes of acidic sites existing in catalysts and the results are revealed in Fig. 4 . The samples exhibited bands at 1440, 1540 and 1490 cm−1, ascribed to Lewis, Brønsted and mix of both acidic sites correspondingly. It is well known that TPA contains only Bronsted acidic sites due to the presence of protons in its secondary structure of Keggin ion. The support TiO2 displayed the existence of small amount of Lewis acidity (Fig. 5 a). When the protons of TPA are exchanged with the Nb ions the catalysts showed the existence of Lewis acidity as shown ion Fig. 5. The IR band intensity of pyridine ion adsorbed on Lewis acidic sites are increased with rise in the loading of Nb0.4TPA on TiO2 [42]. The results indicate that the support TiO2 and Nb ions in TPA responsible for Lewis acidity and Bronsted acidity was mainly generated from TPA. NH3-TPD technique was facilitated to recognize the acidic strength of existing sites and total quantity of acidity. The results are displayed in Fig. 5 and total acidity of the samples are shown in Table 1 . Ammonia desorption peak for TiO2 was observed around 200 °C which was treated as week acidic sites. All the catalysts exhibited a broad desorption peak around 200 °C, signifying that the weak acidic sites which were created from support TiO2. A high temperature desorption peaks was appeared around 450–500 °C allied to medium-strong acidic sites and their intensity was increased with increase in Nb0.4TPA loading [40,43]. The total acidity of catalysts was increased with rise in Nb0.4TPA loading and maximum acidity value was observed for 25wt% of Nb0.4TPA on TiO2. Surface area along with pore size and pore volume values of TiO2, bulk Nb0.4TPA and Nb0.4TPA dispersed on TiO2 catalysts are given in Table 1. Compared with the support TiO2, surface area of the Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 catalysts was low. Surface area, pore size and pore volume were reduced as Nb0.4TPA loading increased on the support. The reduction in surface area, pore volume and pore diameter were attributed to the settling of Nb0.4TPA species inside the support pores and was finely spread on outward surface of the support, which results in fractional blockage in pore walls of the support [44]. Obviously, the support and prepared Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 catalysts showed higher surface area than bulk Nb0.4TPA (SBET = 8.5 m2g−1). 3.2 Activity results 3.2.1 Screening of NBXTPA/TiO2 catalysts for dehydrative etherification of fructose to EMF Initially the reaction was carried over Nb exchanged TPA catalysts containing different amount of Nb. All these catalysts showed good activity towards targeted product EMF as presented in Table 2 . However, these catalysts are homogeneous in reaction mixture. In order to make these catalysts heterogeneous in nature, supported on TiO2. Different quantities of Nb exchanged with protons of TPA supported on TiO2 (20wt% NbxTPA/TiO2 where x = 0, 0.2, 0.4 and 0.6) catalysts were prepared. These prepared catalysts were tested for fructose dehydrative etherification in ethanol/THF medium and their activity outcomes are portrayed in Table 2. TPA supported TiO2 (without Nb) catalyst also studied to clearly know the influence of Nb in the catalysts. All the catalysts including TPA/TiO2 showed high conversion of fructose. However, the selectivity towards desired EMF is more for Nb containing TPA/TiO2 catalysts. When compared to all other catalysts, Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 showed the highest yield of EMF. Catalytic activities of all these catalysts towards EMF are ensuing in the order of Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 > Nb0.6TPA/TiO2 > Nb0.2TPA/TiO2 > TPA/TiO2. The discrepancy in catalytic activity of all these catalysts are directed by the amount of Nb exchanged with the protons of TPA. The increase in amount of Nb presence in TPA increased the Lewis acidity in catalyst thereby the activity towards the targeted product EMF is high. The formation of EMF from fructose was depend on the total acidity and L/B ratio of the catalysts (type of acidic sites). The impact of Lewis to Bronsted acidic sites ratio on the product distribution in dehydrative etherification of fructose was clearly showed in earlier reports [42, 45]. According to these reports Lewis acidic sites more favourable for the formation of EMF than strong Bronsted acids which are favourable for further development of EL. The dehydration of fructose was favoured on Bronsted acidic sites and the etherification was followed on both acidic sites. The greater number of Bronsted acidic sites drives further ring opening product of EL. Pyridine adsorbed FT-IR spectral analysis suggest that the catalyst with low content of Nb has possessed more Bronsted acidity and the creation of Lewis acidic sites was increased with increase in Nb content in catalyst i.e., the L/B ratio was increased with increase in Nb content. The catalyst with reasonable amount of Lewis and Bronsted acidic sites can selectively produce the EMF with more yield. This could be the reason for the high yield of EMF over Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 catalyst. Based on these initial results Nb0.4TPA is taken as active composition and the catalysts are prepared with varying the content of it on TiO2. The catalytic activity outcomes of different loadings of Nb0.4TPA on TiO2 catalysts are depicted in Table 3 . For the sake of assessment, the reaction was performed in the absence of catalyst at 130 °C for 6 h and no EMF was observed. When the reaction was performed with bare Nb0.4TPA, complete conversion of fructose with 63% of EMF yield was obtained. Even though, Nb0.4TPA showed better activity in dehydrative etherification of fructose to EMF it is partially miscible in reaction mixture and makes difficult in catalyst separation for recycle. This bulk catalyst showed more amount of EL, which forms from EMF. The support TiO2 displayed 33% of fructose conversion with 5% of EMF yield. The catalysts activity towards the conversion of fructose improved with enhancement in the Nb0.4TPA loading on TiO2. However, the selectivity towards EMF is increased and reached maximum EMF yield (76%) for the catalyst with 20wt% Nb0.4TPA on TiO2. Further increase in active component to 25wt% produced more EL at the expense of EMF. The discrepancy in activity of 25wt% Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 catalyst might be owed to the being of a greater number of acidic sites which stimulated further EMF transformation to EL. Whereas, 20wt% Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 catalyst have reasonable amount of strong and weak acidic sites which directs the highest yield of EMF. The activity outcomes of the catalysts best coincided with the acidity measures of NH3-TPD and their acidity values signifying that the total acidity of Nb0.4TPA supported catalysts improved with increase in their quantity on the support TiO2. The yield of EMF was relied on the total acidity of catalysts and it was directly proportional to the acidity of catalyst up to 20wt%. Further increase in Nb0.4TPA quantity to 25wt%, decrease in EMF yield and increase in EL yield was detected, the presence of more acidity together with a greater number of strong acidic sites in 25wt% Nb0.4TPA catalyst than balanced amount as in 20wt% favoured for the formation of ring opening product (EL). 3.2.2 Solvent screening over 20wt% Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 catalyst To know the effect of solvent on synthesis of EMF, different solvent systems are examined and the results are presented in Table 4 . The catalyst showed almost complete conversion in all the solvents studied. However, the selectivity to desired product EMF was varied for these solvents. When the experiment was conducted in pure ethanol, EMF and EL are the main products with 67% and 11% yields, respectively. When the DMSO, water and THF as co-solvents along with ethanol (EtOH) the yields of EMF were 45%, 41% and 76% respectively. Compared with ethanol system the yield of EMF was improved when THF used as co-solvent. In case of DMSO and water the produce of EMF was reduced considerably. Water/ethanol or DMSO/ethanol solvent systems may promote the inverse “EMF-HMF” process, as reported earlier [46, 47]. It can be recognized that THF possibly will provide a more hydrophobic atmosphere than ethanol, can separate the products from reactant. This reduces the formation of humins and leads to maximum EMF yield (76%). In case of pure ethanol side reactions such as HMF rehydration and polymerization may occur [48]. In view of the higher EMF yield in ethanol/THF solvent system, THF was used as an effective co-solvent in further studies. 3.2.3 Effect of THF volume As already addressed earlier that the addition of THF as a co-solvent in ethanol medium can enhanced the yield of EMF from fructose over 20wt% Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 catalyst, consequently, we examined the effect of THF volume in ethanol medium towards EMF yield and the results are displayed in Fig. 6 . The introduction of THF could not change in fructose conversion. However, its existence boosted the EMF yield. The maximum yield of EMF was 67% in pure ethanol medium. When 2 mL of THF introduced in to ethanol medium with ethanol/THF volume ratio (VEthanol:VTHF) of 3:2 the yield of EMF was increased to 76%. Further rise in THF amount there was no considerable increase in EMF yield. This might be due to accumulation of HMF and subsequently accessibility of ethanol decreased for etherification. Accordingly, ethanol/THF volume ratio of 3:2 was preferred as the optimum in 5 mL of total solvent. THF presence did not have any noticeable effect on EL yield and it mainly contribute towards hydrophobic atmosphere than ethanol, which can decrease the humins formation by the separation of products from fructose. 3.2.4 Influence of reaction time The progression of fructose dehydrative etherification with 20wt% Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 catalyst at different intervals of time was examined. As shown in Fig. 7 , conversion of fructose and EMF yield were improved by means of time from 1 to 6 h. At early 1 h of reaction time attained only 45% of fructose conversion with 28% and 14% of HMF and EMF yields, respectively. Initially HMF was the major product in the reaction mixture and it was further converted to EMF with increasing the time from 1 to 6 h. Optimal performance was observed at 6 h of reaction time with 99% of fructose conversion and 76% of EMF yield. Further extension of experiment over 6 h led to entire conversion of fructose and the yield EMF was declined. The reduction in EMF yield associated to further ethanolysis of EMF to EL. Above discussion suggests that 6 h of reaction time is optimal for best production of EMF over the present catalyst. 3.2.5 Influence of reaction temperature As established in Fig. 8 , the dehydrative etherification of fructose was carried in the temperature range of 70–150 °C. The conversion and yield of EMF was improved with raising the reaction temperature. At 70 °C of temperature the fructose conversion was only 35%, and reached to 100% when the temperature elevated up to 150 °C. The increase in temperature from 70 to130 °C, EMF yield also progressively improved from 10 to 76% and comparatively reduced to 62% at high temperature i.e.150 °C. At elevated temperatures the reduction in EMF yield might be a result of formation of EL. It indicates that 130 °C is an optimum reaction temperature to get good amount of EMF yield from fructose over 20wt% Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 catalyst. 3.2.6 Catalyst dosage effect The influence of catalyst weight on the dehydrative etherification of fructose was screened and the outcomes are shown in Fig. 9 . Fructose conversion was raised continually by increase in catalyst weight from 0.57 to 4.42 wt%. This might be due to the available number of active sites were increased with increase in catalyst weight. Ideal activity achieved at 3.35 wt% of catalyst weight with 99% and 76% of fructose conversion and EMF yield, respectively. As further raise in catalyst amount to 4.42 wt% complete conversion was noted with reduced EMF yield. The acidity of the catalyst was increased with increase in the amount of catalyst and the high acidity may led to further transformation of EMF to EL. 3.2.7 Merits of the current catalyst over other catalysts In order to explore the advantages of the current catalyst towards dehydrative etherification of fructose to EMF with other catalytic systems, a comparison was made based on the reported catalysts and presented in Table 5 . Different researchers developed acidic catalytic systems containing HPAs and SO3H active components for synthesis of EMF from fructose dehydrative etherification. Liu et al. [49] reported nearly 68% of EMF at 130 οC after 15 h using MIL-101-SO3H catalyst in ethanol/THF medium. Yuan et al. [50] made sulfonated Fe3O4@C catalyst, produced 68% of EMF at 140 οC in longer reaction time of 24 h. Li et al. [29] reported poly (VMPS)-PW catalyst for successive production of EMF, which gave highest yield of EMF (73%) under optimal conditions of 110 οC after 10 h. Acid–base hybrid nanosphere catalyst prepared with heteropoly tungstate and amino acids, reported 76% of EMF yield in ethanol/DMSO solvent system in 15 h reaction time at 120 οC [28]. PWA incorporated SBA-15 catalyst [51] showed 67% of EMF at 100 οC after 24 h. Patrícia A. Russo et al. [46] experimented carbon/silica functionalised with SO3H catalyst in ethanol/water medium for synthesis of EMF from fructose and they reported moderate yields of 33% EMF at 140 οC after 24 h. All the above reported catalytic systems, comparatively produced good amount of EMF. However, they required higher reaction time at moderate to high temperature. Most of these catalysts have issues such as, leaching of active component from the catalyst. Compared to above systems, the present 20wt% Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 catalyst was not leaching and presented higher yield of EMF (76%) within reasonable reaction time. 3.2.8 Reusability The reusability of the 20wt% Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 catalyst was studied under equivalent conditions as done in earlier experiments. Upon end of the experiment, the used catalyst was parted from reaction mixture by centrifugation and washed with ethanol. Dried the collected catalyst at 100 °C and evaluated for recycling experiments under optimum reaction conditions and the outcomes are presented in Fig. 10 . A steady activity of catalyst perceived up to five cycles without major loss in activity. A hot filtration test was performed to identify any active component of the catalyst is leached or not. Fig. 11 shows the results of leaching test. The test results confirmed that there is no leach of active component from the catalyst as there was no conversion after removal of catalyst from reaction mixture. In order to know any structural changes in the catalyst after reuse the used catalyst was examined by XRD and FT-IR. The results are shown in Fig. 12 a and b suggest that the catalyst structure was intact even after repeated use. 4 Conclusions Titania supported Nb exchanged tungstophosphoric acid catalysts were prepared with retention of Keggin ion structure. The catalyst with 20wt% Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 is efficient to produce EMF with 76% yield from fructose in one-pot strategy. Activity of the catalysts was depended on the quantity of Nb ions exchanged with TPA and its content on the support. Lewis acidic sites were created with the replacement of TPA protons with Nb, which are highly influential in the overall acidity of the catalyst. The yield of EMF also be reliant on the reaction time, amount of catalyst and reaction temperature. The catalyst is reproducible and recyclable without any considerable loss in its activity. coredata.dc:description: Various niobium contained tungstophosphoric acid (NbTPA) supported on titania catalysts were prepared and investigated their activity for selective synthesis of 5-ethoxymethylfurfural (EMF) from fructose in ethanol/THF solvent system. Physico-chemical properties of the catalysts were assessed by different spectroscopic approaches like X-ray diffraction, Laser Raman, BET-surface area, FT-IR, pyridine adsorbed FT-IR and temperature programmed desorption of ammonia. The results of characterization direct the existence of firm Keggin ion structure of Nb exchanged TPA and its well dispersed state on support. Lewis acidic sites were induced with the existence of Nb ions. The catalytic activity was interrelated to the catalyst acidity which was liable on the number of Nb ions present in TPA and the amount of NbxTPA supported on TiO2. Among all catalysts 20wt% Nb0.4TPA/TiO2 catalyst showed best catalytic performance towards EMF with a yield of 76% at 130 οC after 6 h. The catalyst is recyclable without any depletion of activity.
coredata.dc:title: Niobium exchanged tungstophosphoric acid supported on titania catalysts for selective synthesis of 5-ethoxymethylfurfural from fructose
